See https://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=57103

The command needed to securely verify a detached signature is:

gpg --verify filename.asc filename

The second parameter must not be omitted.

Hi!

From https://www.gnupg.org/documentation/manpage.html it seems that we are ok:

"""
–verify [[=sigfile=] [=signed-files=]]
Assume that sigfile is a signature and verify it without generating any output. With no arguments, the signature packet is read from stdin (it may be a detached signature when not used in batch mode). If only a sigfile is given, it may be a complete signature or a detached signature, in which case the signed stuff is expected in a file without the ".sig" or ".asc" extension (if such a file does not exist it is expected at stdin; use a single dash ("-") as filename to force a read from stdin). With more than 1 argument, the first should be a detached signature and the remaining files are the signed stuff.
"""

From: http://httpd.apache.org/dev/verification.html

"In this example, you are already assumed to have downloaded httpd-2.0.44.tar.gz (the release) and httpd-2.0.44.tar.gz.asc (the detached signature)."

Closing this bug, please re-open it if I missed something!

The documentation problem still exists.

If an attacker manages to replace the sig file with a self-contained signed file, the release file will not be checked against the sig unless it is specified.

Agreed it is very unlikely - especially if the sig is downloaded from an ASF server - but we should not be giving bad advice.
